Cereal Grain molds.Cause: Complex of fungal pathogens (e.g., Fusarium spp., Alternaria spp., Curvularia spp.) infecting sorghum grain during flowering and grain‐fill, especially under warm humid or rainy conditions. :contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}
Cereal Grain molds.Symptoms: Grains become discoloured (white, pink, grey or black), low grain quality and viability; panicles may show moldy growth. :contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}
Precautions: Use mould‐free seed, harvest promptly when maturity is reached.
Avoid late flowering under humid conditions; ensure good air circulation around panicles.
Rotate sorghum with non‐host crops and manage residues.

Chemical: Apply appropriate seed treatments and fungicide sprays at flowering if high risk identified.
Organic: Improve plant health via good nutrition and avoid stress; use cleanliness and residue management to reduce inoculum.

Covered Kernel smut.Cause: Fungal disease caused by smut fungi that replace kernels with masses of spores, often in kernels covered by plant tissues. :contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}
Covered Kernel smut.Symptoms: Kernels appear normal until heading, then swell and become covered by a membrane containing dark spore masses; infected grains may burst at harvest.
Precautions: Use certified seed and treat seed before planting.
Avoid planting in infested fields repeatedly; rotate crops with non‐hosts.
Sanitise equipment and remove infected crop debris.

Chemical: Seed treatment with systemic fungicide effective against smut organisms.
Organic: Use clean seed, practise crop rotation, and remove and burn infected plants soon after detection.

Head Smut.Cause: Fungal disease (e.g., Sphacelotheca reiliana) affecting sorghum panicles where the inflorescence is replaced by smut mass of spores. :contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}
Head Smut.Symptoms: Panicles are distorted or replaced by black powdery spore masses; may appear at maturity as dark smutty heads instead of normal grain heads.
Precautions: Use resistant varieties and treat seed with recommended fungicide.
Avoid planting in fields known to carry inoculum; rotate crop with non‐host species.
Manage volunteer plants and grasses that may harbour disease.

Chemical: Seed treatment with a recommended fungicide effective against head smut.
Organic: Use disease‐free seed, burn or deep‐bury infected residue, and rotate with non‐host crops.

Red Rot.Cause: Fungal disease (for example caused by Colletotrichum graminicola) which can cause both leaf spot (anthracnose) and red‐rot of stalks under warm, humid conditions. :contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}
Red Rot.Symptoms: Leaves show small red or purple spots that expand; stalks internally show red/orange discoloration and may rot, causing lodging and reduced yield.
Precautions: Rotate crops and manage crop debris; ensure good drainage and avoid excessive nitrogen that favors disease.
Inspect stalks at harvest for early detection of internal rot.

Chemical: Foliar fungicide application during early disease onset; systemic fungicides for stalk rot may be applied if local guidelines allow.
Organic: Use healthy seed and deep‐bury or remove infected residue; maintain plant health and avoid stress to reduce disease susceptibility.

Rust.Cause: Fungal disease caused by Puccinia spp. (e.g., Puccinia purpurea) infecting sorghum leaves under favourable warm, humid conditions. :contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}
Rust.Symptoms: Small reddish‐brown pustules on leaf surfaces, may coalesce to cause leaf‐area loss, reduce photosynthesis and grain fill.
Precautions: Plant resistant varieties and monitor crop regularly during humid periods.
Avoid dense plantings; ensure good airflow and remove volunteer hosts.
Fungicide sprays may be timed when pustules first appear or weather favours spread.

Chemical: Apply foliar fungicides with proven efficacy against rust when threshold reached.
Organic: Maintain plant vigour via good nutrition and avoid stress; remove heavily infected plants if feasible.

Loose Smut.Cause: Fungal disease where spikes or grains are replaced by masses of loose spores, caused by smut fungi such as Sphacelotheca cruenta in sorghum. :contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}
Loose Smut.Symptoms: Inflorescence or grain head appears initially normal then bursts open at maturity releasing loose black spores; affected plants may be stunted and yield reduced.
Precautions: Use certified disease‐free seed and treat dated seed with suitable fungicide before planting.
Avoid harvesting from infected fields and remove infected plants from the crop.
Clean field equipment and practise crop rotation.

Chemical: Seed treatment with appropriate fungicide to eliminate seed‐borne smut inoculum.
Organic: Source smut‐free seed, destroy infected plants and maintain strict hygiene in seed handling.
